wiki_catalogs.name: Tool Overview & Core Value
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for this section focused on the benadis-runner CLI tool. Explain its purpose as an automation utility for 1C:Enterprise development workflows, including database management, configuration conversion, service mode control, and SonarQube integration. Describe the architecture as a modular monolith with clear separation of concerns between components such as app, config, entity, and service packages. Illustrate how the main entry point in main.go routes commands to appropriate handlers via app.go, and how configuration is managed through environment variables and YAML files. Document implementation details including dependency injection, factory patterns, and singleton logger usage. Include practical examples demonstrating common use cases like dbrestore, service-mode-enable, and sq-scan-branch operations. Provide conceptual overviews for beginners while offering technical depth for experienced developers, using terminology consistent with the codebase such as 'entity', 'service', and 'config'. Highlight relationships between core components and external systems like Gitea, SonarQube, and MSSQL.

wiki_catalogs.name: Environment Variables
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the environment variables configuration mechanism in benadis-runner. Explain how the cleanenv library is used to parse and prioritize environment variables over YAML configurations. Document each supported environment variable (e.g., BR_COMMAND, BR_ENV, BR_ACTOR, BR_INFOBASE_NAME) with their purpose, default values, and impact on application behavior. Describe the integration between struct tags in the Config struct and environment variable binding. Provide practical examples of setting up environment variables for different workflows such as database restore, service mode management, and SonarQube scanning. Address common issues like incorrect naming, missing required variables, and type mismatches. Include guidance on best practices for managing environment variables in CI/CD pipelines and local development environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: SonarQube Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SonarQube integration in benadis-runner. Explain the implementation of branch scanning, pull request analysis, and report generation using sonarqube.go and service.go. Document the configuration structure defined in AppConfig.SonarQube and SecretConfig.SonarQube, including token-based authentication. Describe the workflow from command invocation (sq-scan-branch/pr) to SonarQube server communication, covering scanner initialization, resource management, and validation logic. Include concrete examples of API interactions, error handling strategies for timeouts and authentication failures, and retry mechanisms. Illustrate data flow between benadis-runner and SonarQube with sequence diagrams. Address performance considerations such as scan duration optimization and parallel execution constraints. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues like project key mismatches, webhook misconfigurations, and coverage report upload failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: app.yaml Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the app.yaml configuration file in benadis-runner. Explain its role in defining application-wide settings such as logging levels, timeout durations, file paths, and system behavior flags. Document each key in the YAML structure and map them to the corresponding fields in the AppConfig struct within config.go. Provide annotated examples showing valid configurations for different environments (development, staging, production). Detail how these values are loaded, parsed, and merged with environment variables and other configuration sources. Address common issues like incorrect path specifications, invalid timeout values, and misconfigured logging parameters. Include best practices for organizing hierarchical settings and ensuring backward compatibility when extending the schema.

wiki_catalogs.name: Convert Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the convert command in benadis-runner. Explain its purpose of converting 1C:Enterprise projects between formats, particularly from EDT to XML. Document the syntax using BR_COMMAND=convert environment variable, required parameters such as source branch and configuration paths, and return values. Describe the workflow: creating a temporary directory, cloning the repository, switching branches, loading converter configuration, and executing the conversion process. Include examples from app.Convert() function showing parameter validation, error handling for clone/switch failures, and success conditions. Explain how this command integrates with the edt.Convert entity and designer module for actual conversion. Address common issues like branch switching failures and provide troubleshooting guidance. Cover performance considerations for large repositories.

wiki_catalogs.name: sq-scan-branch Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the sq-scan-branch command in benadis-runner. Explain its purpose in initiating SonarQube code quality analysis on a specific 1C:Enterprise project branch. Document the required environment variable BR_COMMAND=sq-scan-branch, along with mandatory parameters such as cfg.BranchForScan and optional commitHash. Describe the full execution workflow: configuration validation, Gitea API initialization via CreateGiteaAPI, temporary directory creation, repository cloning using git.CloneToTempDir, and invocation of HandleSQScanBranchWithCommits. Detail how the function SQScanBranch uses context and structured logging (slog) for observability. Include concrete examples from the code showing error handling patterns for clone failures, scan eligibility checks via shouldRunScanBranch, and proper cleanup with os.RemoveAll. Explain integration points with internal/service/sonarqube package through InitSonarQubeServices and ScanBranchParams. Address common issues like missing access tokens or incorrect branch names, and provide troubleshooting steps. Cover performance considerations such as disk usage for temp directories and network overhead during cloning.

wiki_catalogs.name: Enable Service Mode
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the service-mode-enable command in benadis-runner. Explain its purpose in enabling service mode on a 1C:Enterprise infobase to restrict user access during administrative operations such as configuration updates or maintenance. Document the required environment variable BR_INFOBASE_NAME and optional BR_TERMINATE_SESSIONS flag that forces termination of active sessions. Describe the internal workflow: parsing input parameters, initializing the SlogLogger, loading service mode configuration via LoadServiceModeConfigForDb, creating a client instance, and invoking EnableServiceMode with terminateSessions flag. Include code examples from ManageServiceMode showing how the 'enable' action is handled, including debug, info, and error logging patterns. Explain integration with 1C server processes through RAC (Remote Administration Console) commands and how session termination impacts connected users. Address common issues such as permission errors, unreachable servers, or failure due to locked configurations, and provide troubleshooting guidance. Cover use cases like CI/CD deployments where service mode ensures consistency during automated updates.

wiki_catalogs.name: create-temp-db Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the create-temp-db command (ActCreateTempDb) in benadis-runner. Explain its purpose of creating temporary MSSQL databases for testing and development workflows. Document the required environment variables such as BR_DB_HOST, BR_DB_USER, BR_DB_PASSWORD, and optional parameters like BR_TEMP_DB_NAME. Describe the implementation flow from main.go command routing to app.go execution logic. Include examples from the codebase showing success and error paths, such as database creation failures or connection issues. Explain integration with internal/dbrestore and configuration loading via internal/config. Address common use cases in CI/CD pipelines and potential issues like disk space constraints or permission errors. Provide best practices for cleanup and resource management.

wiki_catalogs.name: Installation Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the installation process of benadis-runner. Explain multiple installation methods available in the codebase including Makefile targets, shell scripts, and containerized deployment via 9-start-container.sh. Document prerequisites such as Go runtime, 1C:Enterprise platform tools (1cv8, ibcmd, rac), and external dependencies like SonarQube scanner and MSSQL drivers. Provide step-by-step instructions for different environments, covering both development setup using install-dev-tools.sh and production deployment scenarios. Include verification steps to confirm successful installation by checking version output and command availability. Address common installation issues such as missing dependencies, permission errors, and PATH configuration problems with specific solutions drawn from the actual implementation. Reference relevant scripts like generate-version.sh and mise.toml for version management and toolchain configuration.

wiki_catalogs.name: YAML Configuration Files
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the YAML-based configuration system in benadis-runner. Explain the structure and purpose of each configuration file: app.yaml for application-wide settings (logging, timeouts, paths), dbconfig.yaml for defining multiple database connections with host, port, credentials, and database names, and action.yaml for GitHub Actions workflow integration. Document how these files are loaded and merged into the central Config struct. Provide annotated examples of valid configurations for each file type. Explain the relationship between YAML keys and the AppConfig, DbConfig, and SecretConfig nested structs in config.go. Address common configuration errors such as invalid YAML syntax, missing required fields, and incorrect data types. Include guidance on organizing configuration files for different environments (development, staging, production).

wiki_catalogs.name: Gitea Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the Gitea integration in benadis-runner. Thoroughly explain implementation details of repository operations including branch creation, commit retrieval, pull request management, and issue tracking through gitea.go. Document the interface abstraction that enables mock testing and extensibility. Detail how access tokens from SecretConfig.Gitea are used for authentication and their scope requirements. Explain usage patterns for Git2Store and storebind workflows that synchronize 1C configurations with Gitea repositories. Include concrete code examples showing branch operations and error handling for rate limits or merge conflicts. Address common issues such as stale references, permission denied errors, and repository synchronization race conditions. Provide best practices for webhook configuration to trigger automated scans and ensure event delivery reliability.

wiki_catalogs.name: dbconfig.yaml Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the dbconfig.yaml configuration file in benadis-runner. Explain its purpose in managing multiple database connection profiles, including hostnames, ports, credentials, and database names. Map the YAML structure to the DatabaseInfo struct and DbConfig map in config.go, detailing how named database entries are resolved at runtime. Provide comprehensive examples of configuration entries for both local and remote MSSQL instances used in 1C:Enterprise environments. Describe how this file integrates with commands like dbrestore and service-mode operations. Address security considerations around credential storage, validation rules for connection strings, and error handling for unreachable databases. Include guidance on environment-specific overrides and testing connectivity through configuration.

wiki_catalogs.name: Dbrestore Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the dbrestore command in benadis-runner. Explain its purpose of restoring MSSQL databases from backups for 1C:Enterprise applications. Document the syntax using BR_COMMAND=dbrestore environment variable, required inputs including database name and connection details from dbconfig.yaml, and expected outputs. Describe the workflow: initializing HASP network key, creating DBRestore instance from configuration, establishing database connection with timeout context, and executing the restore operation. Include examples from DbRestoreWithConfig() function showing error handling for initialization and connection failures. Explain integration with internal/entity/dbrestore package and how it handles backup file discovery and restoration process. Address common issues like connection timeouts and insufficient permissions, providing solutions. Cover performance considerations for large database restores and recommended timeout configurations.

wiki_catalogs.name: sq-scan-pr Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the sq-scan-pr command in benadis-runner. Explain its role in triggering SonarQube pull request analysis within the 1C:Enterprise development workflow. Document the usage pattern with BR_COMMAND=sq-scan-pr environment variable and required configuration fields like cfg.BaseBranch and cfg.Owner. Describe the operational flow: service initialization via InitSonarQubeServices, construction of ScanPRParams, and execution through HandleSQScanPR. Highlight the current implementation limitation where PR number is hardcoded to 0, referencing the TODO comment in the source code. Use the SQScanPR function to illustrate error handling for nil configuration and service initialization failures. Explain integration with Gitea API for PR context retrieval and how it differs from branch scanning. Address common authentication and configuration issues, particularly around missing PR identifiers and base branch mismatches. Provide guidance on expected outputs and logs for successful versus failed scans. Discuss potential enhancements such as automatic PR number detection from CI/CD environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: Disable Service Mode
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the service-mode-disable command in benadis-runner. Explain its role in disabling service mode on a 1C:Enterprise infobase, restoring normal user access after administrative tasks are completed. Document the requirement of BR_INFOBASE_NAME and absence of session-related flags for this operation. Describe the execution flow: validating the disable action, loading database-specific service mode configuration, instantiating the client, and calling DisableServiceMode. Use implementation details from the ManageServiceMode function to illustrate how the 'disable' case is processed, including structured logging of success and failure states. Highlight interactions with the 1C server via RAC tools and emphasize the importance of proper sequencing (e.g., only disabling after successful deployment). Address potential failures such as network timeouts, invalid infobase names, or insufficient privileges, and provide resolution steps. Include real-world scenarios such as post-deployment activation or emergency recovery when service mode was left enabled accidentally.

wiki_catalogs.name: create-stores Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the create-stores command (ActCreateStores) in benadis-runner. Explain its role in initializing configuration storage directories for 1C:Enterprise projects. Document the expected input parameters including base path and project structure definitions. Describe how the command orchestrates directory creation and file initialization through internal utility functions in internal/util and filesystem operations. Detail the workflow from command invocation in main.go to execution in app.go, including error handling for existing directories or insufficient permissions. Include practical examples from actual usage patterns in automation scripts. Address integration with other commands like store2db and git2store, and explain how this supports version control workflows. Cover troubleshooting scenarios such as partial creation failures and recovery procedures.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration Management
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for configuration management in benadis-runner. Explain the hierarchical configuration system that combines environment variables, YAML files, and default values using the cleanenv library. Detail the structure and purpose of each configuration file: app.yaml for application settings, dbconfig.yaml for database connections, and action.yaml for GitHub Actions integration. Document the precedence rules where environment variables override YAML configurations. Describe the Config struct in config.go that serves as the central configuration object with fields for logging, timeouts, paths, and service-specific settings. Provide examples of valid configuration combinations for different use cases. Explain how configuration is loaded and validated at startup, including error handling for malformed or missing configuration values. Address security considerations for storing sensitive data like database credentials and API tokens.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration Precedence Rules
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the configuration precedence system in benadis-runner. Explain the hierarchical override order where environment variables take priority over YAML file values, which in turn override hardcoded defaults in the Config struct. Document the technical implementation using the cleanenv library's layered approach to configuration loading. Illustrate with concrete examples how setting BR_COMMAND=dbrestore overrides the command field in app.yaml. Describe the validation process that occurs after all configuration layers are applied. Address edge cases such as empty string overrides, boolean flag handling, and slice/array merging behavior. Provide troubleshooting guidance for diagnosing unexpected configuration values by showing how to trace the source of each final configuration value. Include performance considerations regarding configuration loading speed and memory usage.

wiki_catalogs.name: 1C:Enterprise Platform Integration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the 1C:Enterprise platform integration focusing on service mode management. Explain how servicemode.go orchestrates RAC (Remote Administration Console) commands via rac.go to enable, disable, and check service mode states in 1C information bases. Document the domain model including connection parameters, infobase identifiers, and cluster management. Include usage examples for service-mode-enable/disable/status commands with proper parameterization. Detail error handling for scenarios like unreachable clusters, locked infobases, or invalid credentials. Explain the relationship between environment variables, configuration files, and command-line arguments in determining target 1C base. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common issues such as 'infobase not found', 'access denied', and 'timeout during service mode transition'. Address security considerations around credential storage and transmission when managing production 1C environments.

wiki_catalogs.name: action.yaml Configuration
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the action.yaml configuration file in benadis-runner. Explain its role in enabling GitHub Actions workflow integration by defining command mappings, environment variable bindings, and execution contexts. Document how this file supports CI/CD pipelines for 1C:Enterprise projects by specifying entry points for automated tasks such as sq-scan-branch, execute-epf, and git2store. Provide real-world examples of workflow definitions that trigger benadis-runner commands based on pull requests or scheduled events. Map relevant sections to the Config struct's Command, Env, and Actor fields in config.go. Address common pitfalls like incorrect command naming, missing environment propagation, and permission issues in CI environments. Include best practices for securing secrets and maintaining reproducible builds across pipeline runs.

wiki_catalogs.name: Service Mode Commands
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the service mode commands (service-mode-enable, service-mode-disable, service-mode-status) in benadis-runner. Explain their purpose in managing 1C:Enterprise service mode for administrative operations. Document the syntax using respective BR_COMMAND values, required parameters like BR_INFOBASE_NAME, and return values. Describe the workflow: validating infobase name, creating SlogLogger wrapper, and calling servicemode.ManageServiceMode with appropriate action ('enable', 'disable', 'status'). For service-mode-enable, cover the terminateSessions parameter for forcing session termination. Include examples from the implementation showing error handling for missing infobase names and service operation failures. Explain integration with the servicemode package and how it interacts with 1C server processes. Address common issues like active sessions preventing disable operations and provide troubleshooting guidance. Cover use cases for maintenance windows and deployment scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Check Service Mode Status
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the service-mode-status command in benadis-runner. Explain its function in retrieving the current service mode state of a 1C:Enterprise infobase, including whether service mode is active and the count of active user sessions. Document the use of BR_INFOBASE_NAME as the sole required parameter and describe how the command outputs status information via structured logs. Detail the internal process: action validation, configuration loading, client creation, and invocation of GetServiceModeStatus. Reference the ManageServiceMode implementation to show how the 'status' action returns a response containing Enabled and ActiveSessions fields. Explain how this command supports decision-making in automation pipelinessuch as determining if it's safe to proceed with a deployment or identifying lingering sessions. Address possible errors like connection failures or misconfigured RAC paths, and provide diagnostic tips. Illustrate usage in monitoring scripts and pre-flight checks before enabling service mode.

wiki_catalogs.name: storebind Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the storebind command (ActStoreBind) in benadis-runner. Explain its function of binding 1C configuration storage to a target infobase, enabling synchronization workflows. Document required parameters such as BR_INFOBASE_NAME, BR_STORE_PATH, and authentication credentials. Describe the implementation flow that connects to the 1C server via RAC (internal/rac) and executes binding operations. Include examples from the codebase showing successful binding sequences and error conditions like invalid paths or connection timeouts. Explain integration points with git2store and store2db commands, forming a complete sync pipeline. Address security considerations when handling credentials and provide guidance on idempotent operations. Cover common issues such as stale locks or version mismatches and their resolution strategies.

wiki_catalogs.name: Command Reference
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for all available commands in benadis-runner. Document each command's purpose, syntax, parameters, and return values based on their implementation in main.go and app.go. Cover primary commands including convert, dbrestore, service-mode-enable/disable/status, git2store, store2db, sq-scan-branch/pr, and execute-epf. For each command, explain its workflow, required inputs, expected outputs, and interaction with other components. Include concrete examples from the codebase showing parameter validation, error handling, and success conditions. Describe how commands are dispatched through the BR_COMMAND environment variable and mapped to corresponding functions in the app package. Document exit codes and their meanings for automation scripting. Address common usage patterns and anti-patterns for each command based on test cases and real-world scenarios.

wiki_catalogs.name: Git2store Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the git2store command in benadis-runner. Explain its purpose of synchronizing configuration from Git repository to 1C configuration storage. Document the syntax using BR_COMMAND=git2store environment variable, required inputs like repository URL and branch information, and expected outputs. Describe the workflow: initializing NetHasp, creating temporary directory, setting up Git instance with access token, cloning repository, switching to EDT branch, handling local base creation with temporary database, binding to configuration storage, updating database, dumping configuration, merging changes, and committing to storage. Include examples from Git2Store() function showing error handling at each step. Explain integration with git.Git and one/convert.Config components. Address common issues like merge conflicts and storage lock failures, providing solutions. Cover performance considerations for large configuration sets and recommended timeout settings.

wiki_catalogs.name: dbupdate Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the dbupdate command (ActDbupdate) in benadis-runner. Explain its purpose in updating database schemas for 1C:Enterprise applications after configuration changes. Document required inputs including connection details, update mode (schema-only vs full), and optional flags for backup creation. Describe the execution flow from command dispatch in main.go to business logic in app.go, leveraging internal/dbrestore utilities for safe operations. Include examples from actual implementations showing parameter combinations and expected output formats. Explain integration with convert and store2db commands in typical deployment pipelines. Address critical concerns such as transaction safety, rollback procedures, and performance impact during updates. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common failure modes like constraint violations or timeout errors.

wiki_catalogs.name: Advanced Integrations
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for advanced integration features in benadis-runner. Focus on three key integrations: SonarQube for code quality analysis, Gitea for version control operations, and 1C:Enterprise platform for service mode management. For SonarQube, document the scanning workflow implemented in sonarqube.go and service.go, including branch scanning, pull request analysis, and report generation. For Gitea, explain repository operations like branch management and issue tracking through the gitea.go interface. For 1C integration, detail how servicemode.go controls service mode states in 1C bases. Describe authentication mechanisms, API rate limiting considerations, and error recovery strategies for each integration. Include diagrams illustrating data flow between benadis-runner and external systems. Provide troubleshooting guidance for common integration issues like connection timeouts, authentication failures, and data synchronization problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Store2db Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the store2db command in benadis-runner. Explain its purpose of synchronizing configuration from 1C configuration storage to database. Document the syntax using BR_COMMAND=store2db environment variable, required inputs including infobase name and storage connection details, and expected outputs. Describe the workflow: loading configuration, binding to storage, and applying configuration changes to the database. Include examples from Store2Db() and Store2DbWithConfig() functions showing different configuration loading approaches. Explain the difference between the basic and 'WithConfig' variants that allow custom configuration files. Describe integration with one/convert.Config entity for storage operations. Address common issues like storage binding failures and provide troubleshooting guidance. Cover use cases for deploying configuration changes to test and production environments, referencing TaskStore2DbTest and TaskStore2DbProd constants.

wiki_catalogs.name: sq-project-update Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the sq-project-update command (ActSQProjectUpdate) in benadis-runner. Explain its role in refreshing SonarQube project metadata, such as name, description, or visibility settings. Document required configuration including SONAR_HOST, SONAR_TOKEN, and project identifier (BR_SONAR_PROJECT_KEY). Describe the implementation using internal/entity/sonarqube package to make API calls for project updates. Include examples from the codebase showing successful updates and error responses like unauthorized access or invalid parameters. Explain integration within CI/CD workflows where project metadata needs synchronization. Address rate limiting considerations, authentication methods, and response handling. Provide troubleshooting tips for connectivity issues and debugging strategies using verbose logging.

wiki_catalogs.name: Configuration Details
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive data model documentation for configuration files in benadis-runner. Detail the structure of app.yaml including sections for logging, timeouts, paths, and service-specific settings with their respective data types and validation rules. Document dbconfig.yaml schema with fields for server, port, database name, authentication, and connection pool settings. Explain the menu configuration files (menu_main.yaml and menu_debug.yaml) that define UI templates for different operational modes. For each configuration element, specify default values, allowed ranges, and interdependencies between settings. Include sample configurations for different deployment scenarios. Document how these YAML files are parsed into the Config struct in config.go using gopkg.in/yaml.v3. Address advanced configuration topics like environment-specific overrides, sensitive data handling, and configuration validation during startup.

wiki_catalogs.name: SonarQube Scan Commands
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the SonarQube scanning commands (sq-scan-branch, sq-scan-pr) in benadis-runner. Explain their purpose in performing code quality analysis on 1C:Enterprise projects. Document the syntax using BR_COMMAND=sq-scan-branch or sq-scan-pr environment variables, required inputs like SonarQube server URL and project keys, and expected outputs. Describe the workflow: initializing SonarQube services, creating scan parameters, and executing branch or pull request scans. For sq-scan-branch, explain the use of commit hash parameter. For sq-scan-pr, describe pull request-specific analysis. Include examples from SQScanBranch() and SQScanPR() functions showing error handling and service initialization. Explain integration with internal/service/sonarqube package and Gitea API for pull request context. Address common issues like authentication failures and provide troubleshooting guidance. Cover performance considerations for large codebases and recommended resource allocation.

wiki_catalogs.name: sq-report-branch Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the sq-report-branch command (ActSQReportBranch) in benadis-runner. Explain its function of generating quality reports for SonarQube-scanned branches, including metrics, issues, and hotspots. Document required inputs such as BR_SONAR_PROJECT_KEY, BR_BRANCH_NAME, and output format preferences. Describe the implementation flow that retrieves analysis data from SonarQube API via internal/service/sonarqube components and formats the report. Include examples from the codebase showing different report types and integration with notification systems. Explain how this command fits into pull request validation workflows and quality gate enforcement. Address performance considerations for large projects and caching strategies. Provide guidance on interpreting results and troubleshooting missing data or API limitations.

wiki_catalogs.name: Error Handling & Exit Codes
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for error handling mechanisms and exit codes in benadis-runner. Document the centralized error handling approach implemented across the codebase, including custom error types defined in various entity packages and consistent error propagation patterns. Explain the meaning and usage of each exit code returned by the application, particularly how they indicate different failure modes for automation scripts. Describe the structured logging implementation using slog that captures error context, stack traces, and diagnostic information. Cover error recovery strategies for transient failures like network timeouts and database connection issues. Provide troubleshooting guidance organized by error type, referencing specific log messages and their root causes. Include examples of common error scenarios from QWEN.md and actual test cases, with recommended solutions and workarounds.

wiki_catalogs.name: Execute-epf Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the execute-epf command in benadis-runner. Explain its purpose of executing external processing files (.epf) in 1C:Enterprise applications. Document the syntax using BR_COMMAND=execute-epf environment variable, required inputs including path to .epf file and target infobase connection details, and expected outputs. Describe the workflow: initializing NetHasp, creating EpfExecutor with working directory, and executing the external processing file. Include examples from ExecuteEpf() function showing error handling for nil configuration and execution failures. Explain integration with enterprise.NewEpfExecutor and how it interfaces with 1C command-line tools. Address common issues like file permission errors and incompatible .epf versions, providing solutions. Cover use cases for automated data migration, report generation, and system maintenance tasks.

wiki_catalogs.name: test-merge Command
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for the test-merge command (ActTestMerge) in benadis-runner. Explain its purpose in simulating merge operations between 1C configuration branches to detect conflicts before actual merging. Document required parameters including source and target branch identifiers, temporary workspace paths, and conflict detection thresholds. Describe the implementation flow from command parsing in main.go to merge simulation logic in app.go, utilizing 1C platform tools via command-line interfaces. Include examples from actual usage showing successful simulations and detected conflict scenarios. Explain integration with CI/CD pipelines for automated merge validation. Address limitations of the simulation approach and provide best practices for interpreting results. Cover common issues such as tool version compatibility and workspace cleanup failures.

wiki_catalogs.name: Development Guide
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content for developers contributing to benadis-runner. Explain the codebase architecture with its modular design separating concerns into app, config, entity, service, and util packages. Document the process for adding new commands, including registering them in main.go, implementing business logic in app.go, and creating corresponding tests. Detail the testing strategy evident from the extensive test coverage across all packages, emphasizing the importance of unit tests, integration tests, and coverage goals. Provide guidelines for writing effective tests following existing patterns in *_test.go files. Explain the build and release process using Makefile and Taskfile.yml. Cover coding standards, documentation requirements, and contribution workflow. Include debugging techniques and performance profiling methods used in the project.

wiki_catalogs.name: Other Commands
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed content for additional commands in benadis-runner beyond the primary ones. Cover commands such as create-temp-db (ActCreateTempDb), create-stores (ActCreateStores), storebind (ActStoreBind), dbupdate (ActDbupdate), sq-project-update (ActSQProjectUpdate), sq-report-branch (ActSQReportBranch), and test-merge (ActTestMerge). For each command, explain its specific purpose, syntax using corresponding BR_COMMAND values, required parameters, and expected outcomes. Describe workflows based on their implementation in main.go and app.go. For example, create-temp-db creates temporary databases for testing, while sq-project-update refreshes SonarQube project metadata. Include examples from the codebase showing parameter usage and error conditions. Explain how these specialized commands support broader development workflows and integrate with other components. Address common use cases and potential issues for each command.

wiki_catalogs.name: Troubleshooting
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Develop detailed troubleshooting content for common issues encountered when using benadis-runner. Organize problems by category such as configuration errors, database connectivity issues, 1C platform integration problems, and SonarQube scanning failures. For each issue, provide diagnostic steps, log analysis techniques, and verified solutions. Include specific fixes documented in reports like git_index_lock_fix_report.md and analysis_report.md. Address environmental factors like file permissions, network connectivity, and resource limitations. Document known limitations and workarounds for edge cases observed in test scenarios. Provide a systematic approach to problem isolation, starting from command invocation through configuration parsing to external system interactions. Include decision trees for rapid issue resolution and escalation paths for unresolved problems.

wiki_catalogs.name: Examples & Use Cases
wiki_catalogs.prompt: Create comprehensive content showcasing practical examples and real-world use cases for benadis-runner. Document complete workflows such as setting up a CI/CD pipeline with GitHub Actions using action.yaml templates, automating database restores with dbconfig.yaml configurations, and implementing quality gates with SonarQube scanning. Include annotated script examples from the scripts directory demonstrating environment setup, version management, and container operations. Provide scenario-based tutorials for common development tasks like converting 1C projects, synchronizing configuration between storage and database, and managing service mode states. For each use case, explain the business value, required configuration, expected outcomes, and potential pitfalls. Reference example configurations in the config directory and demonstrate how to adapt them for different environments.

wiki_overview.content:
<blog>
# Comprehensive Project Analysis: benadis-runner

## 1. Project Introduction

### Purpose Statement
The benadis-runner is a comprehensive automation tool designed for managing and automating development workflows for 1C:Enterprise applications. The tool provides a unified interface for various operations including database management, configuration conversion, service mode control, and integration with development tools.

### Core Goals and Objectives
- Automate repetitive tasks in the 1C:Enterprise development lifecycle
- Provide a centralized configuration system for all modules
- Enable seamless integration between different components of the 1C ecosystem
- Support automated testing and quality assurance through SonarQube integration
- Facilitate continuous integration and deployment processes

### Target Audience
- 1C:Enterprise developers and administrators
- DevOps engineers working with 1C applications
- System integrators managing multiple 1C instances
- Quality assurance teams requiring automated testing capabilities

## 2. Technical Architecture

### Component Breakdown
The project follows a modular architecture with clear separation of concerns:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[Client Interface] --> B[Command Router]
    B --> C[Configuration Manager]
    B --> D[Application Logic]
    D --> E[Service Modules]
    E --> F[External Systems]
    
    subgraph "Core Components"
        C[Configuration Manager]
        D[Application Logic]
        E[Service Modules]
    end
    
    subgraph "Service Modules"
        E1[Convert Module]
        E2[DBRestore Module]
        E3[ServiceMode Module]
        E4[EDT Module]
        E5[SonarQube Integration]
    end
    
    subgraph "External Systems"
        F1[1C:Enterprise Platform]
        F2[Gitea Repository]
        F3[SonarQube Server]
        F4[MSSQL Database]
    end
    
    C -->|Provides config| D
    D -->|Executes commands| E1
    D -->|Executes commands| E2
    D -->|Executes commands| E3
    D -->|Executes commands| E4
    D -->|Executes commands| E5
    E1 -->|Interacts with| F1
    E2 -->|Interacts with| F4
    E3 -->|Interacts with| F1
    E4 -->|Interacts with| F2
    E5 -->|Interacts with| F3
```

### Design Patterns
The application implements several design patterns:
- **Dependency Injection**: Configuration and services are injected into components
- **Factory Pattern**: For creating different types of entities and services
- **Strategy Pattern**: Different implementation strategies for various operations
- **Singleton Pattern**: For shared resources like logging and configuration

### System Relationships
The system relationships demonstrate how different components interact:

```mermaid
graph LR
    A[Main Entry Point] --> B[Configuration Loader]
    B --> C[Command Dispatcher]
    C --> D[Convert Module]
    C --> E[DBRestore Module]
    C --> F[ServiceMode Module]
    C --> G[EDT Module]
    C --> H[SonarQube Module]
    D --> I[1C Platform]
    E --> J[MSSQL Database]
    F --> K[1C Platform]
    G --> L[Gitea Repository]
    H --> M[SonarQube Server]
```

### Data Flow Diagrams
The data flow illustrates how information moves through the system:

```mermaid
flowchart TD
    A[User Input] --> B[Environment Variables]
    B --> C[Configuration Files]
    C --> D[Config Parser]
    D --> E[Central Config]
    E --> F[Command Executor]
    F --> G[Module Specific Logic]
    G --> H[External Systems]
    H --> I[Results]
    I --> J[Logging]
    J --> K[Output]
```

## 3. Key Implementation

### Main Entry Points
- [main.go](cmd/benadis-runner/main.go)

### Core Modules
- [app.go](internal/app/app.go)
- [config.go](internal/config/config.go)
- [constants.go](internal/constants/constants.go)

### Configuration Approach
- [config.go](internal/config/config.go)
- [app.yaml](config/app.yaml)
- [dbconfig.yaml](config/dbconfig.yaml)

### External Dependencies
- [sonarqube.go](internal/entity/sonarqube/sonarqube.go)
- [scanner.go](internal/entity/sonarqube/scanner.go)

### Integration Points
- [service.go](internal/service/sonarqube/service.go)
- [gitea.go](internal/entity/gitea/gitea.go)

### Component Relationship Diagrams
The component relationships show the hierarchical structure:

```mermaid
graph TD
    A[benadis-runner] --> B[Core Application]
    A --> C[Configuration System]
    A --> D[Service Modules]
    A --> E[Utility Functions]
    
    B --> B1[Command Processing]
    B --> B2[Error Handling]
    B --> B3[Logging]
    
    C --> C1[Environment Variables]
    C --> C2[YAML Files]
    C --> C3[Default Values]
    
    D --> D1[Convert Module]
    D --> D2[DBRestore Module]
    D --> D3[ServiceMode Module]
    D --> D4[EDT Module]
    D --> D5[SonarQube Module]
    
    E --> E1[File Operations]
    E --> E2[Git Operations]
    E --> E3[Template Processing]
```

## 4. Key Features

### Functionality Overview
The benadis-runner provides comprehensive functionality for 1C:Enterprise development and administration:

1. **Database Management**: Restore, update, and manage MSSQL databases
2. **Configuration Conversion**: Convert between different 1C configuration formats
3. **Service Mode Control**: Enable/disable service mode for 1C bases
4. **Version Control Integration**: Work with Gitea repositories and EDT
5. **Code Quality Analysis**: Integrate with SonarQube for code analysis
6. **Automated Testing**: Execute external processing files (.epf)

### Implementation Highlights
- [main.go](cmd/benadis-runner/main.go) - Central command dispatching
- [app.go](internal/app/app.go) - Business logic implementation
- [sonarqube.go](internal/entity/sonarqube/sonarqube.go) - SonarQube API integration
- [scanner.go](internal/entity/sonarqube/scanner.go) - SonarScanner execution

### Feature Architecture Diagrams
The state diagram shows the workflow of key features:

```mermaid
stateDiagram-v2
    [*] --> Idle
    Idle --> ProcessingCommand: Command received
    ProcessingCommand --> LoadingConfig: Load configuration
    LoadingConfig --> ExecutingAction: Execute action
    ExecutingAction --> Success: Action completed
    ExecutingAction --> Error: Action failed
    Success --> Idle: Reset
    Error --> Idle: Reset
    
    note right of ProcessingCommand
        Supported actions:
        - convert
        - dbrestore
        - service-mode-enable
        - service-mode-disable
        - sq-scan-branch
        - sq-scan-pr
    end note
```

The sequence diagram illustrates the SonarQube scanning process:

```mermaid
sequenceDiagram
    participant User
    participant CLI
    participant Config
    participant SonarQubeService
    participant SonarScanner
    participant SonarQubeServer
    
    User->>CLI: Run sq-scan-branch
    CLI->>Config: Load configuration
    Config-->>CLI: Return config
    CLI->>SonarQubeService: Initialize service
    SonarQubeService->>SonarScanner: Download scanner
    SonarScanner-->>SonarQubeService: Scanner path
    SonarQubeService->>SonarScanner: Configure scanner
    SonarScanner-->>SonarQubeService: Ready
    SonarQubeService->>SonarScanner: Execute scan
    SonarScanner->>SonarQubeServer: Send analysis
    SonarQubeServer-->>SonarScanner: Accept analysis
    SonarScanner-->>SonarQubeService: Scan results
    SonarQubeService-->>CLI: Results
    CLI-->>User: Display results
```
</blog>
